Etymology[edit]

You can help Wiktionary by providing a proper etymology.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (female given name) enPR: hălē, IPA(key): /ˈhæli/

Proper noun[edit]

Halle

  1. A city in Saxony-Anhalt, Germany.
  2. A female given name.

Anagrams[edit]

  • Hella, hella, hella-

German[edit]

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ˈhalə/
  • Rhymes: -alə

Etymology 1[edit]

From Middle High German halle, from Old High German halla, from Proto-Germanic *hallō, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *ḱel- (“to hide, cover, conceal”). Compare Low German Hall, Dutch hal, English hall, Danish and Swedish hall.

Noun[edit]

Halle f (genitive Halle, plural Hallen)

  1. hall
Declension[edit]
Declension of Halle

genitiveeinerderHallederHallen
dativeeinerderHalledenHallen
accusativeeinedieHalledieHallen
Derived terms[edit]
  • Hallenbad, Hallenschwimmbad, Schwimmhalle
  • Kaufhalle
  • Leichenhalle
  • Spielhalle

Etymology 2[edit]

Attested in early manuscripts as Halla.

Proper noun[edit]

German Wikipedia has an article on:
Halle (Saale)
Wikipedia de

Halle n (genitive Halles)

  1. Halle, a city in Saxony-Anhalt near the river Saale, Germany
  2. any of several other cities with the same name
Synonyms[edit]
  • (Halle, city in Saxony-Anhalt): Halle an der Saale, Halle a/S., Halle a. d. S., Halle a. S.
